newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Forecasts for NZ '96 kiwifruit selling season rise.
newsitem.headline: Forecasts for NZ '96 kiwifruit selling season rise.

text.p: The 1996 kiwifruit selling season is now expected to net NZ$1.5 million more than was forecast in August, according to the Kiwifruit Marketing Board.
The September forecast for the selling season is NZ$257.6 million, up from the August forecast of $256.1 million.
The average return per tray has also risen, to $4.13 from $4.11 in August.
The 1996 forecast orchard gate return per hectare improved to $15,495 from $14,739 in 1995.
Statutory board chairman John Palmer said continued good performance in Japan, East Asia and emerging markets had contributed to the improvement in the board's September forecast position.
The board has scheduled a grower payment for late October, subject to achieving sales targets and meeting bank commitments.
It said its global position year to date was on track, ahead of 1995 and 1994, with around 60 percent of the crop sold.

Year to date volumes sold in Europe were 500,000 trays higher than at any time in the board's history. Kiwifruit sales into Europe had gone against the trend of general decline in consumer fresh fruit consumption, due to significant promotional activity and effort across all European markets.
Sales in Japan and East Asia continued to be strongly ahead of 1995.
